thread.title: Vicious storm drops 6 inches of snow on New York in two hours
thread.title_full: Vicious storm drops 6 inches of snow on New York in two hours - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Vicious storm drops 6 inches of snow on New York in two hours
text:
A “super intense” snowstorm dumped 6 inches of snow on the city in just two hours Thursday, crippling local airports as the mayor encouraged New Yorkers to stay inside.
Forecasters predicted anywhere from 10 to 14 inches of snow would blanket the five boroughs before the first major winter storm of 2017 begins to abate in the afternoon.
“This is an unusually fast, intense storm,” Mayor de Blasio told a news conference. “It’s very tough conditions out there, very hard to get around.”
JFK Airport was shut down for all departing flights shortly after 11 a.m. as the heavy snow and gusting winds wreaked havoc on the three local airports — with more than 1,100 flights canceled, according to the flight-tracking website FlightAware.
Fourteen city buses became stuck in the snow during the morning rush hour as the power of the storm ramped up and the temperatures dropped into the 20s — a plunge of more than 30 degrees from Wednesday, when the mercury hit 60.
15 photos view gallery Sun vs. Snow: New York City hit with snow storm day after record-breaking heat Tribeca building superintendent Kanto Kamaj echoed the mayor’s take on the fast-falling snow.
“I am (shoveling) the sidewalks,” said Kamaj, 43. “It’s going good, but as soon as you finish one side you have to start all over again because it’s coming down.”
A winter storm warning was in effect through 6 p.m. Thursday, with most of the heavy snow expected to end a few hours earlier.
By 11:30 a.m., there were 9 inches of snow at LaGuardia Airport in Queens and 8.5 inches on Staten Island, with 6 inches reported in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.
A powerful, fast-moving storm swept through the northeastern U.S. Thursday, making for a slippery morning commute and leaving some residents bracing for blizzard conditions. (Anthony DelMundo/New York Daily News) The city dispatched 2,300 snowplows and spreaders, with the mayor — who toured Astoria, Long Island City and Jackson Heights in Queens — pleased with the Sanitation Department response.
“They’re out in full force and doing a good job,” the mayor said. “They’re going at it really hard, really well.”
De Blasio rebuffed a question about whether New York was becoming a city of wimps, with the school-closing announcement made early Wednesday and his repeated calls for people to stay home and off the streets.
“It’s just plain common sense not to go out if you don’t have to, to stay home, to keep your car home,” said de Blasio. “It’s not a moral judgment. It’s not that we’ve changed who we are.”
Travelers sit stranded at LaGuardia Airport in Queens as the hefty snowfall kept air traffic grounded. (MIKE SEGAR/REUTERS) The mayor predicted schools will reopen on Friday, and announced alternate side of the street parking was suspended for Friday and Saturday.
“This day obviously was disrupted by Mother Nature,” the mayor said. “Tomorrow I want to be as normal as it can be.”
UPS delivery person Andy Alvarez said the weather was making work a lot more challenging.
“On a regular day I would probably load eight boxes on my hand truck,” he explained. “But today, I’ll only load four. I’ve got to be safe. Driving, too. You can’t go over 20 miles per hour.”
Technician Michael Barrett said the roads were unplowed for his ride from Jersey City into Manhattan.
“I was late to work,” he said. “Coming into the city took me about 35, 40 minutes. I would rather be home right now.”
